title-group.article-title: Discretionary Accruals Quality, Cost of Capital, and Diversification

article-meta.aff: 3The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX, USA

abstract.p: This study examines the discretionary accruals quality of single- and multiple-segment firms. The authors hypothesize and find that the discretionary accruals quality is lower for multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms, and for the same level of discretionary accruals quality, the cost of capital is higher for multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms. These findings suggest that more severe agency problems in multiple-segment firms compared with single-segment firms may lead to poor discretionary accruals quality and agency risk is priced-in as a higher cost of capital.

body.p: We examine whether discretionary accruals quality differs across single-segment and multiple-segment firms and whether the discretionary accruals quality impacts their respective costs of capital differently. We argue that multiple-segment firms are likely to have more internal agency problems than single-segment firms and as such, we hypothesize that multiple-segment firms are likely to have lower discretionary accruals quality than single-segment firms. Consistent with this hypothesis, we find that multiple-segment firms have lower discretionary accruals quality than single-segment firms. In examining the relationship between discretionary accruals quality and cost of capital, we find that for the same level of discretionary accruals quality multiple-segment firms have higher cost of capital than single-segment firms do.

Single-segment firms have less internal agency problems than multiple-segment firms, that is, compared with single-segment firms, multiple-segment firms have more hidden-action and hidden-information agency problems between top management and divisional managers (Chandler, 1991; Henderson & Fredrickson, 1996; Michel & Hambrick, 1992). To mitigate such internal agency problems, multiple-segment firms more likely compensate their division managers according to level of earnings within a reporting period than single-segment firms (Demski, 1994; Healy & Palepu, 2001; Lambert, 2001). In addition, compared with multiple-segment firms, single-segment firms’ top management is likely to monitor their division managers more effectively because their business model focuses on one segment. Thus, single-segment firms are less likely to link compensation to jointly observable financial measures (Aron, 1988; Rotemberg & Saloner, 1994; Stulz, 1990). Single-segment firms are less likely to tie their management compensation to earnings, and therefore managers are less likely to manipulate earnings (Fields, Lys, & Vincent, 2001; Healy & Palepu, 2001). Such a managerial opportunism argument leads us to hypothesize that those discretionary accruals of multiple-segment firms are likely to be of lower quality than those of single-segment firms.

We measure discretionary accruals quality in two ways. Our first measure captures how well accruals map into the cash flows and follows the procedure developed in Dechow and Dichev (2002) and Francis, LaFond, Olsson, and Schipper (2004, 2005) studies. In particular, firm-specific accruals quality is measured as the standard deviation of the residuals obtained from regressing accruals on past, current, and future cash flows as well as fundamental variables, namely, the change in revenues and plant, property, and equipment within a 5-year estimation window. Our second measure is based on the absolute value of performance adjusted abnormal total accruals (Kothari, Leone, & Wasley, 2005). Using Francis et al.’s (2004, 2005) procedure, we decompose both measures of accruals quality into innate and discretionary components. Discretionary accruals quality is our measure of information quality that reflects managerial opportunism.

Consistent with our hypothesis, we find that the discretionary accruals of multiple-segment firms are of lower quality than those of single-segment firms. Noting that the innate accruals quality is related to the fundamental business model, we find that innate accruals of multiple-segment firms are of better quality than those of single-segment firms. This highlights the importance of controlling for innate factors when examining the hypothesis of managerial opportunism across firms with differing business models (see Francis et al., 2005).

Hidden-action and hidden-information agency problems result in an agency risk that partly determines the cost of equity capital, that is, agency risk is priced-in and investors demand a risk premium for poor information quality (Easley & O’Hara, 2004; Jensen & Meckling, 1976; Lambert, Leuz, & Verrecchia, 2007). Empirical evidence supports this theoretical prediction (Bhattacharya, Daouk, & Welker, 2003; Ecker, Francis, Schipper, & Olsson, 2006; Francis et al., 2004, 2005).1 Following Guay, Kothari, and Watts’s (1996) argument, discretionary accruals consist of three components: signaling, opportunism, and noise. As discussed earlier, discretionary accruals in multiple-segment firms are more likely to be due to managerial opportunism than in single-segment firms.2 As such, for the same level discretionary accruals purged of the innate component is likely to be more due to managerial opportunism for multiple-segment firms than for single-segment firms. The discretionary accruals quality based on the Dechow and Dichev (2002) and Francis et al. (2004, 2005) measure captures the consistency with which accruals map into cash flows. Compared with single-segment firms, multiple-segment firms’ accruals may not map into cash flows well due to managerial opportunism, and likely to do so consistently, resulting in a higher discretionary accruals quality measure. Thus, the same discretionary accruals quality score across single- and multiple-segment firms are likely to indicate different levels of agency problems. Accordingly, we hypothesize that compared with single-segment firms, multiple-segment firms have a higher cost of capital for the same level of discretionary accruals quality.3

We follow Easton (2004) for the cost of equity capital estimation and Francis, Nanda, and Olsson (2008) for the cost of debt estimation by coding the Standard & Poor (S&P) debt ratings scores on a 20-point scale. Consistent with our hypothesis, we find that for a given level of discretionary accruals quality, multiple-segment firms have a higher cost of capital than single-segment firms. We also find that for a given level of innate accruals quality, multiple-segment firms have a lower cost of capital than single-segment firms. This suggests that in empirical settings, fundamental differences due to business models are important to consider.

This study contributes to the literature in two ways. First, diversified firms provide a good context to examine the interaction between agency problems, discretionary accruals quality, and cost of capital. We provide insights into the interrelationships between internal agency problems, information risk, and cost of equity capital.4 Second, we show the association between internal agency costs as proxied by single- and multiple-segment firms and discretionary accruals quality. Accordingly, multiple-segment firms have lower discretionary accruals quality than single-segment firms.5 In establishing this link, we show the importance of controlling for the differences in earnings quality that are associated with the business model. In particular, recognizing that single-segment firms’ business models are considerably different from those of multiple-segment firms, we show that innate accruals quality of multiple-segment firms is of better quality than that of single-segment firms. This leads to total accruals quality of multiple-segment firms being of better quality than that of single-segment firms.

The rest of the article is organized as follows: Hypotheses are developed in the section titled “Hypothesis Development,” the section titled “Empirical Analysis” provides the research design and empirical results, the section titled “Discretionary Accruals Quality and Excess Value of Diversification” examines the association between discretionary accruals quality and diversification discount, and the last section provides some concluding remarks.

sec.title: Hypothesis Development
sec.p: In this section, we first develop the hypothesis relating agency problems and discretionary accruals quality of multiple- and single-segment firms and then develop the hypothesis relating discretionary accruals quality and cost of capital of multiple- and single-segment firms.

sec.title: Agency Cost and Discretionary Accruals Quality
Internal Agency Costs of Single- and Multiple-Segment Firms
sec.p: On one hand, diversification is likely to have potential economic benefits. Chandler (1977) argues that multiple-segment firms could operate and coordinate activities more efficiently than single-segment firms. Multiple-segment firms could be more efficient in allocating resources because they can diversify income flows to avoid inefficient bankruptcies and exploit economies of scope (Gertner, Scharfstein, & Stein, 1994; Lewellen, 1971; Stein 1997; Williamson, 1970).

On the other hand, agency costs that arise due to information asymmetry between the top management and the division managers are exacerbated in multiple-segment firms. Berg (1969, 1973) and Lorsch and Allen (1973) argue that corporate headquarters of multiple-segment firms has little knowledge of the firms’ business units, therefore they decentralize various decisions. Chandler (1991) examines a small sample and empirically shows that there are more divisions and executives in multiple-segment firms than in single-segment firms, which is indicative of the existence of high information asymmetry in multiple-segment firms. In comparing multiple-segment firms with single-segment firms, Michel and Hambrick (1992) show that multiple-segment firms have larger size and different composition of top management teams than that of single-segment firms to manage the information asymmetry problems. Moreover, Henderson and Fredrickson (1996) show that in multiple-segment firms, CEO compensation is more positively associated with information processing demand. Collectively, these articles show that internal agency problems are more severe in multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms.

sec.title: Relating Internal Agency Costs and Discretionary Accruals Quality
sec.p: To mitigate internal agency problems, multiple-segment firms are likely to compensate their division managers based on observable performance measures (Bushman & Smith, 2001; Demski, 1994; Healy & Palepu, 2001; Lambert, 2001). Single-segment firms are more focused, thus they are likely to be more effective monitors of divisional managers.6 Consequently, single-segment firms are likely to compensate their managers based on the information about managers’ effort obtained through direct monitoring and rely less on observable financial measures. Thus, compared with single-segment firms, multiple-segment firms are more likely to compensate their managers based on observable performance measures such as earnings. Bushman, Indjejikian, and Smith (1995) document that as the degree of product-line diversification increases, relative use of division-level, accounting-based performance measures increases. Similarly, Keating (1997) finds that in evaluating division managers, the use of division-level, accounting-based metrics increases with diversification. Moreover, he finds that for diversified firms, divisional accounting metrics are the most important, followed by firm accounting metrics, and firm stock price. As management compensation of single-segment firms is less likely to be tied to divisional earnings, single-segment firms’ earnings are less likely to be manipulated (Fields et al., 2001; Healy & Palepu, 2001).

We measure discretionary accruals quality in two ways (see sections titled “Measures of Discretionary Accruals Quality” and “Research Design”). Our first measure captures how well accruals map into cash flows and follows the procedure developed in Dechow and Dichev (2002) and Francis et al. (2004, 2005). In particular, firm-specific accruals quality is measured as the standard deviation of the residuals obtained from regressing accruals on past, current, and future cash flows as well as fundamental variables, namely, the change in revenues and plant, property, and equipment within a 5-year window. Our second measure is based on the absolute value of performance-adjusted abnormal total accruals (Kothari et al., 2005). Using Francis et al.’s (2004, 2005) procedure, we decompose both measures of accruals quality into innate and discretionary components. Discretionary accruals quality is our measure of information quality that reflects managerial opportunism.

Guay et al. (1996) provide a framework that suggests three elements of discretionary accruals quality: an element that signals future performance, an element that arises due to managerial opportunism, and an element that is pure noise. Healy (1996) notes that managerial opportunism component dominates the signaling component in carefully selected nonrandom samples. Holding the signaling and noise components constant across multiple- and single-segment firms, we posit that because of managerial opportunism, multiple-segment firms are likely to have lower discretionary accruals quality than single-segment firms. The following hypothesis summarizes these arguments.7

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1 (H1): Compared with single-segment firms, multiple-segment firms are likely to have lower discretionary accruals quality, ceteris paribus.

sec.p: The alternative hypothesis to H1 is the efficient contracting perspective, which suggests that multiple-segment firms would commit to reporting higher quality earnings to mitigate their higher internal agency problems. However, Skinner (1993) shows that the managerial opportunism effect dominates the efficient contracting outcome in explaining observed accounting choices. If this is not the case, our H1 may not hold.

sec.title: Cost of Capital and Discretionary Accruals Quality
Information Risk and Cost of Capital
sec.p: Easley and O’Hara (2004) model information risk arising from information asymmetry across informed and uninformed investors and show that the quantity and quality of information affect stock prices, resulting in cross-sectional differences in the cost of equity capital. Lambert et al. (2007) show that information quality can potentially influence the cost of capital in two ways. First, higher information quality may affect the firm’s covariance of cash flows with other firms and second, higher information quality may affect the firm’s real operating decisions, which in turn changes the ratio of expected future cash flows to the covariance of the cash flows. Several studies in the literature show that higher information quality is associated with decreased cost of equity capital because information quality improves stock liquidity (see Amihud & Mendelson, 1986; Copeland & Galai, 1983; Diamond & Verrecchia, 1991; Glosten & Milgrom, 1985). Hughes, Liu, and Liu (2007) examine the information risk in a multifactor asset pricing model and show that information risk is either diversified or captured by existing risk factors. As such, the assertion that information risk is priced-in, that is, information risk is not a diversifiable risk factor, is contentious in the theoretical literature (for discussions on the information risk pricing debate see also Indjejikian, 2007).

Recently, a number of empirical studies find that cost of capital and earnings quality is negatively associated. Francis et al. (2005) find that accruals quality is priced-in factor, that is, firms with poor accruals quality have higher cost of capital. They also find that the innate component of accruals quality has larger cost of capital effects than the discretionary component of accruals quality. Francis et al. (2004) find that the largest cost of capital effects are due to the accruals quality measure of Dechow and Dichev (2002). Bhattacharya et al. (2003) find a negative association between the average country-level cost of capital and earnings quality for 34 countries. Berger, Chen, and Li (2006) use the ratio of variation in returns to change in cash flows as a measure of information quality and show a negative association between information quality and cost of capital. These findings employing various measures of earnings quality and cost of capital suggest that earnings quality is priced-in. In summary, even though the link between earnings/information quality and cost of equity capital is still debated in theoretical research, the link is fairly well established in empirical research.

sec.title: Relating Cost of Capital and Discretionary Accruals Quality of Single- and Multiple-Segment Firms
sec.p:
As discussed in H1, managerial opportunism likely drives the difference in discretionary accruals quality of single- and multiple-segment firms. Francis et al. (2005) argue that the signaling effect would decrease the information risk, whereas managerial opportunism and the noise components of discretionary accruals quality would increase the information risk. If managerial opportunism component of discretionary accruals was higher for multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms (see development of H1), then the information risk of multiple-segment firms would be higher than that of single-segment firms as well. The discretionary accruals quality based on the Dechow and Dichev (2002) and Francis et al. (2004, 2005) procedures capture the stability with which accruals map into cash flows. Francis et al. (2005) state,
Larger standard deviations of residuals indicate a poorer accruals quality. However, if a firm has consistently larger residuals so that the standard deviation of this residuals is small, that firm has relatively good accruals quality because there is little uncertainty about its accruals. For such a firm, the accruals map poorly into cash flows, but this is a predictable phenomenon, and should not be a reason for priced uncertainty. (p. 303)

Compared with single-segment firms, multiple-segment firms’ accruals may not map into cash flows as well due to managerial opportunism but are likely to do so consistently. Given that the discretionary accruals quality measure captures the consistency with which accruals map into cash flows, even though single- and multiple-segment firms have different levels of agency problems and information risk, they may obtain the same discretionary accruals quality score. Similarly, the same level of absolute value of performance-adjusted discretionary accruals purged of the innate component is likely to contain a higher portion due to managerial opportunism for multiple-segment firms than for single-segment firms. Thus, for the same level of discretionary accruals quality, compared with single-segment firms, we expect a positive association between the discretionary accruals quality and the cost of capital for multiple-segment firms. This is stated in the following hypothesis.8

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2 (H2): Compared with single-segment firms, multiple segment firms’ discretionary component of accruals quality is more positively associated with cost of capital.

sec.p: Multiple-segment firms could commit to do better disclosure practices to mitigate the potential for lower quality of reported earnings. Bens and Monahan (2004) provide evidence that excess value of diversified firms is positively associated with the quality of disclosures. To the extent that such committed disclosure practices dominate the reported discretionary accruals quality effect, H2 may not hold. Underlying the arguments developed for H1 and H2 is the notion that in equilibrium the second-best solution obtains (Jensen & Meckling, 1976). In other words, the internal agency problems in multiple-segment firms lead to nonzero agency costs. Thus, committing to report better discretionary accruals with high quality or better disclosure practices could be useful to mitigate the additional agency costs at a certain level, but that commitment may not remove it entirely.

sec.title: Empirical Analysis
sec.p: In this section, we provide the research design and the empirical evidence for H1 and H2.

sec.title: Measures of Discretionary Accruals Quality
sec.p: We use two measures of discretionary accruals quality: one based on the association of accruals with cash flows (Dechow & Dichev, 2002) and the other based on the absolute value of performance adjusted discretionary accruals using the cross-sectional Jones model (Kothari et al., 2005). First, we define the computation of these measures, and then we explain their decomposition into innate and discretionary accruals quality.

sec.title: Accruals Quality Measure of Dechow and Dichev (2002)–ACCQ
sec.p: The accruals quality (ACCQ) metric is based on the cross-sectional Dechow and Dichev (2002) model, augmented with the fundamental variables from the Jones model (see McNichols, 2002).

ΔCAj,t is the change in current assets, ΔCLj,t is the change in current liabilities, ΔCASHj,t is the change in cash, and ΔSTDEBTj,t is the change in short-term debt in current liabilities for firm j between years t− 1 and t. CFOj,t is the cash flow from operations of firm j in year t computed as the difference between the net income before extraordinary items and total accruals (TAj,t). Total accruals of firm j in year t is TAj,t = TCAj,t–DEPNj,t, where DEPNj,t is the depreciation and amortization expense at year t for firm j. We estimate Equation (1) annually for each of Fama and French’s (1997) 48 industry groups having at least 20 firms and obtain firm-year specific residuals. ACCQj,t is the standard deviation of firm j’s residuals calculated from t− 4 to t. As a result, large values of ACCQ measure indicate lower accruals quality than small values of ACCQ.

sec.p: Consistent with Kothari et al. (2005), we estimate the cross-sectional Jones model for each two-digit Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) industry group having at least 20 firms in year t as below.

The industry- and year-specific estimates obtained from estimating Equation (2) are used to compute normal accruals (NAj,t) where NAj,t is the predicted value from Equation (2). The difference between TAj,t and NAj,t is the abnormal (discretionary) accruals for firm j in year t. Following Kothari et al. (2005), firm j in year t is matched with a companion firm with the closest return on assets in the same two-digit SIC code in year t. The difference in abnormal accruals of firm j and its companion firm’s is PADTA, which stands for performance adjusted discretionary accruals. ABSDA is the absolute value of PADTA, which is our second measure of accruals quality. Similar to ACCQ, large values of ABSDA indicate lower accruals quality than small values and as such, ABSDA is also a reverse-ordered measure of accruals quality.

We estimate Equation (3) for each year, and the estimated residual from Equation (3) is the measure of the discretionary component of accruals quality of firm j in year t; when the dependent variable in Equation (3) is ACCQ (ABSDA), the discretionary component of accruals quality is DISC_ACCQ (DISC_ABSDA): DISC_EQj,t = {DISC_ACCQj,t, DISC_ABSDAj,t}. Correspondingly, the predicted value of EQj,t from Equation (3) is the measure of innate accruals quality (INNATE_EQ): INNATE_EQj,t = {INNATE_ACCQj,t, INNATE_ABSDAj,t}. Both DISC_EQ and INNATE_EQ are reverse-ordered with higher values indicating lower accruals quality and vice versa.9

An important point to note is that even though prior research uses the absolute value of PADTA as the measure of earnings quality (Bartov, Gul, & Tsui, 2000; Becker, Defond, Jiambalvo, & Subramanyam, 1998; Klein, 2002; Warfield, Wild, & Wild, 1995), we decompose the absolute value of PADTA into innate and discretionary components. We do this for two reasons: First, our hypotheses are based on managerial opportunism. In the empirical analysis section, we show that multiple-segment firms are considerably different from single-segment firms on each of innate factors; thus, there are fundamental differences in the business model across these firms. As argued by Dechow and Dichev (2002) and Francis et al. (2005), if there are differences between the business models of multiple-segment and single-segment firms, then accruals quality is likely to be different. Thus, it is likely that the cross-sectional Jones model may not adequately capture the differences in abnormal accruals due to such fundamental differences.10 Second, we use the decomposed absolute value of PADTA measure so that we can present the results of the empirical analysis in a parsimonious fashion.

MULTISEG is an indicator variable that takes a value of one if the firm reports more than one segment in year t and is zero otherwise: Single-segment firms have a value of zero, whereas multiple-segment firms have a value of one for MULTISEG. LOGMVE is the natural logarithm of the market value of equity (MVE) where MVE is computed as the stock price at the fiscal year-end times the number of shares outstanding. MERGER is an indicator variable with the value one if the company had a merger in year t and zero otherwise. FINANCING is a dummy variable with a value one if MERGER is not equal to one and the number of outstanding shares increased by 10% or the long-term debt increased by 20% or the firm first appeared on the Center for Research in Securities Prices (CRSP) monthly returns database during the fiscal year, and zero otherwise.

LITIGATION is a dummy variable that equals the value of one if the firm operates in a high-litigation industry (SIC codes of 2833-2836, 3570-3577, 3600-3674, 5200-5961, and 7370) and zero otherwise. LEVERAGE is calculated as the ratio of total debt to average total assets. MB is the ratio of MVE over book value of equity. LOSS is an indicator variable that equals one if the net income before extraordinary items is negative (less than zero) and zero otherwise. INSTITUTION is the percentage of shares held by institutions, that is, the number of shares held by institutions obtained from proxy statements divided by the total number of shares outstanding. CFO is cash flows from operation, which is net income before extraordinary items minus total accruals, all scaled by average total assets. L1ACCRUAL is lagged total accruals scaled by average total assets. BIG5 is a dummy variable that takes the value of one if firm is audited by one of the Big Five auditors and zero otherwise. These control variables are included to rule out the possibility of mechanical and other noninternal agency problem–related relationships identified in prior research to drive our results (see Ali, Chen, & Radhakrishnan, 2007; Ashbaugh et al., 2003). We rank all continuous independent variables into deciles and scale them to range from zero to one. We do this to ensure that extreme values of the explanatory variables do not drive the results.

Our variable of interest is MULTISEG. Based on H1 and noting that DISC_EQ is reverse-ordered with lower signed values indicating better quality than higher signed values, we expect the coefficient estimate δ1 to be positive.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: The sample contains all firms from the COMPUSTAT Industrial Annual database and the Segment database between the years 1984 and 2003. Similar to Berger and Ofek (1995), we eliminate the firms where the sum of the segment sales is not within 1% of the total net sales. The final sample contains 35,460 firm-year observations with 23,356 (12,104) firm-year observations for single- (multiple-) segments representing 4,723 (2,305) distinct single- (multiple-) segment firms.

Panel A of Table 1 provides some descriptive statistics for the innate factors used to estimate Equation (3) for single- and multiple-segment firms.11 Mean (median) ASSET is US$782 (US$135) million for single-segment firms and US$2,005 (US$372) million for multiple-segment firms suggesting that multiple-segment firms are larger than single-segment firms. STDCFO has a mean (median) of 0.0965 (0.0759) for single-segment firms and 0.0759 (0.0593) for multisegment firms indicating that the variation in cash flow from operations of single-segment firms is higher than that of multiple-segment firms. STDSALES value is divided by hundred to get comparable values with the other coefficient of statistics. Standard deviation of sales has a mean (median) value of 1.7199 (0.3647) for single-segment firms and 3.8088 (1.0049) for multisegment firms representing that the variation in sales of single-segment firms is lower than that of multiple-segment firms. The mean (median) CYCLE is 140 (128) days for single-segment firms and 134 (123) days for multiple-segment firms showing that the operating cycles are quite similar for both single- and multiple-segment companies. The mean (median) NEG_EARN is 0.3576 (0.3000) for single-segment firms and 0.2170 (0.1000) for multiple-segment firms, indicating that multiple-segment firms are on average less likely to report negative earnings in comparison with single-segment firms. All mean and median differences between single- and multiple-segment firms are statistically significant at conventional levels. Collectively, these descriptive statistics indicate that the accruals quality of single- and multiple-segment firms are likely to be different due to fundamental differences in the business model; therefore, we should control for these in the empirical analyses to reach accurate conclusions. In addition, based on Francis et al. ’s (2005) results, the differences in innate factors across single- and multiple-segment firms are likely to induce better accruals quality for multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms.

sec.p: The mean (median) ACCQ and ABSDA are 0.0479 and 0.0841 (0.0404 and 0.0661) for single-segment firms and 0.0387 and 0.0742 (0.0307 and 0.0549) for multiple-segment firms, respectively, and the mean and medians differences are statistically significant. This shows that total accruals quality of multiple-segment firms is better than that of single-segment firms. However, note that the fundamental differences in the business models across single- and multiple-segment firms, that is, the difference in the innate factors, are likely to contribute to the better overall accruals quality of multiple-segment firms. That is, to test H1, we need to control for the fundamental differences in accruals quality and consider the discretionary component of accruals quality.

Panel B of Table 1 provides pooled regression estimates of Equation (3). In panel-data regression estimates, the robust standard errors for computing the t statistics are adjusted for clustering at firm level (Petersen, 2009). Consistent with Francis et al. (2005), we find that all innate factors other than LOGASSET are positively associated with accruals quality measures, ACCQ and ABSDA, and LOGASSET is negatively associated with ACCQ and ABSDA. The explanatory power of the innate factors is 44.43% for ACCQ and 10.72% for ABSDA. Although the explanatory power of the innate factors with ACCQ is similar to the one reported in Francis et al., the explanatory power with ABSDA is considerably lower potentially because ABSDA already incorporates the discretionary accruals component of accruals quality.

sec.title: H1
sec.p: Panel A of Table 2 provides the descriptive statistics for the variables in Equation (4). The mean (median) discretionary accruals quality, DISC_ACCQ and DISC_ABSDA, are −0.0033 and −0.0063 (−0.0065 and −0.0211) for single-segment firms and −0.0013 and −0.0058 (−0.0034 and −0.0192) for multiple-segment firms, respectively. This indicates that discretionary accruals of multiple-segment firms are of lower quality than those of single-segment firms. This finding provides initial support for H1. sec.p: In estimating Equation (4), we annually rank all the nonindicator independent variables into deciles and scale them to be in the (0, 1) range. We do this in all our estimation models, so that we can interpret the coefficient estimates as the marginal difference between the highest and lowest deciles. We also include fixed year and industry effects in the panel-data regressions and fixed industry effects in the annual Fama–MacBeth estimations. The industry dummies are based on 12 industry groups as defined in Fama and French (1997). We estimate Equation (4) from 1986 to 2003 because data on institutional ownership is available from 1986 onwards.12

Panel B of Table 2 provides the results of estimating Equation (4). We estimate Equation (4) with all observations and adjust standard errors for firm clustering to obtain robust standard errors. We report the results in the column “Pooled.” We also estimate Equation (4) annually and use the standard error of the annual estimates, that is, the Fama–MacBeth procedure that we report in the column “Fama–MacBeth.” In the pooled estimation, the coefficient estimate on MULTISEG with DISC_ACCQ and DISC_ABSDA as dependant variables are 0.0014 (t = 2.07) and 0.0012 (t = 2.09), respectively. Thus, controlling for other demand and supply factors that influence the discretionary accruals quality, we find that multiple-segment firms have lower discretionary accruals quality than single-segment firms. The estimates using the Fama–MacBeth procedure are qualitatively similar to the pooled estimates. Overall, the results are consistent with H1.13

Even though we predicate H1 for discretionary accruals quality, we conduct the empirical analysis for innate accruals quality as an exploratory effort. We do this to explore whether the differences in innate factors across multiple- and single-segment firms are likely to affect inferences if such factors are not considered separately. Table 2, Panel C reports the estimation of Equation (4) with innate accruals quality (INNATE_ACCQ and INNATE_ABSDA) instead of discretionary accruals quality (DISC_ACCQ and DISC_ABSDA). In the pooled-estimation, the coefficient estimate on MULTISEG with INNATE_ACCQ and INNATE_ABSDA as dependant variables are −0.0031 (t = −7.77) and −0.0031 (t = −6.73), respectively. This shows that the accruals that occur due to the business model are of better quality in multiple-segment firms than in single-segment firms.

In the Fama–MacBeth estimation, with DISC_ACCQ and DISC_ABSDA as the measures of discretionary accruals quality, the coefficient estimate on the interaction term, α12 are 0.0117 (t = 1.84) and 0.0015 (t = 2.20), respectively. This result is consistent with H2. The discretionary accruals quality and the innate accruals quality are positively associated with the cost of equity capital as in Francis et al. (2005). In addition, similar to Francis et al., the cost of equity capital is more strongly associated with the innate accruals quality than the discretionary accruals quality.

In the Fama–MacBeth estimation, the coefficient estimate on the interaction term, α12, when DISC_ACCQ and DISC_ABSDA are the measures of discretionary accruals quality are 0.1392 (t = 1.02) and 0.2266 (t = 2.43), respectively. These results are qualitatively similar to those discussed above in Panel B. Overall, the results provide support for H2.15

Our results suggest that for the same level of innate accruals quality, the multiple-segment firms’ cost of equity and debt capital are lower than that of single-segment firms (the coefficient on the interaction between innate accruals quality and MULTISEG is negative). This shows that accruals quality score based on the consistency of how accruals map into cash flows may not adequately capture the real accruals quality, and future research can focus on examining this.

sec.title: Sensitivity Tests
sec.p: We perform a number of sensitivity tests. First, we use continuous measures instead of the rankings for explanatory variables other than the DISC_EQ and INNATE_EQ in Equations (4) and (5). The results are qualitatively similar and are consistent with H1 and H2.

Second, we examine whether the earnings response coefficient (ERC) as a measure of earnings quality is different across multiple- and single-segment firms. We augment the ERC model in Ali et al. (2007) by replacing their family firm’s dummy with MULTISEG and by creating an interaction term between change in earnings and MULTISEG. Based on H1 and H2, we predict the coefficient of the interaction between MULTISEG and change in earnings to be negative. The change in earnings per share is the measure of “new information that comes to the market.” If multiple-segment firms have higher cost of capital than single-segment firms, then for the same change in earnings per share, ERC would be higher for single-segment firms than multiple-segment firms. To see this, consider an earnings capitalization model, up until perpetuity with permanent earnings surprise y. That is, the change in earnings y is permanent up until perpetuity. If the cost of capital of multiple-segment firms is higher than that of single-segment firms, then price reaction for multiple-segment firms would be lower than that of single-segment firms, ceteris paribus. Of course, this could also indicate that the earnings change of single-segment firms is more persistent than that of multiple-segment firms, which would also lead to lower price reaction for multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms. Overall, we predict a negative coefficient on the interaction term of MULTISEG and ΔEPS, either due to the direct effect of earnings quality, that is, persistence of earnings changes, or the indirect effect of earnings quality through cost of equity capital. We find that the coefficient on the interaction between MULTISEG and ΔEPS is −0.113 (t = −2.94). This finding suggests that the information contained in earnings is discounted possibly because the earnings quality is lower for multiple-segment firms compared with that of single-segment firms, ceteris paribus. Overall, these results provide indirect support to the hypothesis that accounting information quality for multiple-segment firms is lower than that for single-segment firms.

Third, we examine the signed performance adjusted abnormal accruals and their relationship with the future cash flows across single- and multiple-segment firms. We find that large positive abnormal accruals for single- (multiple-) segment firms are positively (not) associated with next period’s cash flows. Large negative abnormal accruals are associated with next period’s cash flows for both single- and multiple-segment firms in a similar fashion. Given that positive abnormal accruals are more likely to arise due to managerial opportunism, the result is consistent with H1.

sec.title: Discretionary Accruals Quality and Excess Value of Diversification
sec.p: In this section, we explore the relationship between discretionary accruals quality and excess value (diversification discount). Lang and Stulz (1994) show that multiple-segment firms trade at a discount compared with a companion portfolio of single-segment firms. The Tobin’s q of multiple-segment firms is less than the Tobin’s q they would have if separated into portfolios of single-segment firms. Similarly, Berger and Ofek (1995) show that the market value of equity and debt to sales of multiple-segment firms is less than the market value of equity and debt to sales if they would have been separated into portfolios of single-segment firms, that is, the diversification discount. Lamont and Polk (2001) examine the future expected return differences across single- and multiple-segment firms using first-order vector autoregression. They find that slightly more than half of the difference is attributable to future cash flow differences and about one fifth of the difference is attributable to the cost of capital differences. This indicates that the diversification discount documented by Berger and Ofek is partly due to higher cost of capital, that is, future expected return differences and partly due to cash flow differences.16

Empirical tests of H2 indicate that for the same level of discretionary accruals quality, multisegment firms have a higher cost of capital than single-segment firms. However, fundamental differences across single- and multiple-segment firms in terms of innate accruals quality suggests that diversification discount should be lower for multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms due to fundamental differences.

sec.p: To explore this issue further, we examine the signed performance adjusted abnormal accruals and their relationship with excess value. We find that large positive abnormal accruals for single- (multiple-) segment firms are positively (not) associated with excess value, and large negative abnormal accruals are associated with excess value for both single- and multiple-segment firms in a similar fashion. Given that positive abnormal accruals are more likely to arise due to managerial opportunism, the results are consistent with investors demanding a higher premium for lower information quality in multiple-segment firms or that the investors recognizing that positive abnormal accruals of multiple-segment firms are not associated with the future cash flows. These results also provide support for the signaling role of discretionary accruals for single-segment firms overall.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: We examine the relationship between discretionary accruals quality across single- and multiple-segment firms under the assumption that managerial opportunism (internal agency problem) is likely to be more severe in multiple-segment firms. We find that the quality of discretionary accruals is lower in multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms, and the quality of accruals based on fundamentals of the business model is higher in multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms. We then examine the association between the cost of capital and the discretionary accruals quality for single- and multiple-segment firms. We find that multiple-segment firms have a higher cost of capital than single-segment firms for the same level of discretionary accruals quality. This indicates that managerial opportunism, more severe agency problems, in multiple-segment firms is priced-in factor in capital markets. We also show that multiple-segment firms have a lower cost of capital than single-segment firms for the same level of innate accruals quality. These findings suggest that the measure of discretionary accruals quality based on the consistency with which accruals map into cash flows is likely to incorporate fundamental aspects such as agency problems and business model elements, which provide avenues for future research.

Hughes, Liu, and Liu (2007) shows that information risk is captured by existing risk factors and is not priced.
This argument assumes that the other components of discretionary accruals are similar across single- and multiple-segment firms.
We do not hypothesize the relationship between the innate accruals quality and cost of capital because our focus is on differential agency problems across single- and multiple-segment firms.

Although Francis, LaFond, Olsson, and Schipper (2005), among others, show that earnings quality is associated with cost of capital and thus is a priced-in risk factor, Core, Guay, and Verdi (2008) claim that Francis et al.’s (2005) regressions examining a contemporaneous relationship between excess returns and factor returns do not test the hypothesis that earnings quality is a priced-in risk factor and document that earnings quality is not a priced risk factor. By examining diversified firms, we provide evidence on the relationship between discretionary accruals quality and cost of capital, that is, whether information risk is a priced-in risk factor in a specific context.
This is similar to empirical studies that examine the accounting quality across family and nonfamily firms (see Ali, Chen, & Radhakrishnan, 2007; Wang, 2006).

Direct monitoring by the single-segment firms’ top management and their better knowledge of the firms’ business due to their focused strategy may be additional reasons why managers’ opportunistic behavior is less likely to affect earnings quality of single-segment firms. For example, single-segment firms’ top managers’ knowledge of business conditions and their relationships with suppliers and customers will enable them to detect effectively whether goods have been shipped early to inflate revenues.

Bushman and Smith (2001) provide arguments for how the complexity of multiple-segment firms is likely to result in poor information quality (also see Bushman, Indjejikian, & Smith, 1995; Keating, 1997).

Hypothesis 2 will hold, even if the noise component of discretionary accruals is higher for multiple-segment firms than single-segment firms due to their difference in complexity. As such, the general construct is one of the difference in internal agency problems due to differences in complexity.

The estimation of DISC_ABSDA is similar but not identical to estimating Equation (2) after including the five innate factors. It is not identical because in computing PADTA, we match firms based on closest return on assets and then estimate Equation (3) annually for all firms.
Inclusion of the five innate factors as control variables in the tests of Hypotheses 1 and 2 yields qualitatively similar results.
We winsorize all nonindicator variables at 1st and 99th percentiles. In the multivariate tests, we use decile ranks.
Estimating Equation (4) without institutional ownership from 1984 to 2003 yields qualitatively similar results.
As a robustness test, we estimated Equation (4) just with firms which did not go through a merger and found qualitatively similar results.
We estimated Equations (5a) and (5b) without the interaction of MULTISEG and INNATE_EQ and obtained similar results.
We estimated cost of capital and debt regressions after including an indicator variable for whether the firm reports a loss in the current year and found qualitatively similar results.

Graham, Lemmon, and Wolf (2002) examine firms that increase their number of segments through mergers and acquisitions and find that acquiring firms have a diversification discount because they acquire already discounted business units. Villalonga (2004a, 2004b) uses establishment level data from Business Information Tracking Series and shows that diversification discount is an “artifact” of aggregation in companies’ reporting practices. Campa and Kedia (2002) show that diversified firms are fundamentally different and thus controlling for endogeneity of diversification choice, the diversification discount does not exist. These articles’ objective is to demonstrate that diversification does not destroy value as is implied by the diversification discount. Various theoretical and empirical support exists for diversification discount to prevail in equilibrium when agency costs and synergies are considered (Aggarwal & Samwick, 2003; Gomes & Livdan, 2004; Hund, Monk, & Tice, 2010).

This is similar to the finding in Core, Guay, and Verdi (2008) that accruals quality is negatively associated with future stock returns. One argument they propose for this result is that realized returns are a biased proxy for expected returns if arrival of good news and bad news do not cancel each other.
